concept.title: Collation
concept.shortdesc: DITA provides guidance for collation through the <index-sort-as> element.

conbody.p: The term collation refers to determination of the order (collating sequence) in which character strings should be placed when sorting them, typically for processed index output. Even where languages share the same general character set, such as within the set of Western European languages, collating sequence often varies according to language and locale. Even where languages share the same writing system or script, as for Western European languages, the rules for collation may vary based on language, locale, and local editorial practices. In addition, some languages, such as Japanese and Simplified Chinese, use ideographic scripts where collation is determined by factors such as pronunciation or the number of ideographic strokes, rather than the specific characters used.

Processing applications implement collation using a combination of standard algorithms and processor-specific configurations for things like grouping rules, handling of character variants, and sorting of English before or after non-English languages.
One practical way to specify an alternate collating sequence is with the <index-sort-as> element within the <indexterm> element.

DITA-aware processors will process and collate the index entry "[foo]" as "foo" in output. <index-sort-as> may also specify a custom collating scheme to be used by a specialized processor. <index-sort-as> provides the semantic to specify alternate collating sequences without enumerating or specifying what those sequences might be.
